div.head: The Lesson of War
div.p: The whole fortnight of carnage, probably un- equalled in the history of modern warfare, and certainly greater than that of Yen-tai and of Liao-yang has resulted in an unquestionable disaster to the Russian arms. We say, ad- visedly, a disaster, becuase whatever propor- tions it may finally take - the battle of Mukden is essentially different from its predecessor. Consternation reigns at St. Petersburg, de- spite the efforts of a terrified Government to prevent full knowledge of the truth, and in friendly Paris, which has been thoroughly

div.head: The Tosh Whisky
div.p: Established 1726.
Mackintosh & C. Inverness.
Agents: M. Eleftherion & Co. Cairo & Alexandria.
Retailers. E. J. Fleurent, Square Halim Pacha, Cairo.

div.head: The Lesson of War
div.p: loyal to the Grand Ally, profound sorrow pre- vails. But, alike in the Russian and in the French capitals, public opinion must be even more moved by a very human horror at the terrible slaughter which has been inflicted than at the political consequences of the Russian disaster, grave though these must necessarily be. Our own people, and the whole civilised world, will share the natural abhorrence of humanity at the spectacle of such frightful loss in a struggle which would never have been entered upon but for the overweening arrogance and fatuous blind- ness of the men who have brought it to pass. May we not venture to hope that in this universal horror there may be found a potent influence capable of making for peace. It is, we believe, an undeniable fact that there is a great, though hitherto noiseless, wave of reaction aganist militarism sweeping over the Continent of Europe. After more than thirty years of a truce which has been kept by two nations armed to the teeth, the French and German peoples are heartily sick of the burden of everlasting preparation for war. It is impos- sible to watch the trend of events in France and Germany without perceiving that fact. In France military service is daily grow- ing more and more unpopular, and mili- tary discipline more and more difficult to maintain. In Germany the extraordinary growth of Social Democracy is making for the same results. Italy has reduced her military strength to a point which proves clearly that she has no intention od being drawn into war if she can possibly avoid it. Again, in Austria- Hungary, the language dispute has gone to prove the one-half of the Dual Monarchy does not set military matters, above all other considerations In 'England, too, the suggestion of uni- versal service has - rightly or wrongly - evoked unmistakable signs of popular opposition. As to Russia, we know that the unfortunate reservists can only be compelled by force to join their regiments, and leave for the seat of war. Is it, then, too much to hope that the terrible fate of all the vic- tims of Yentai, of Liao-Yangm of port Ar- thur, of Mukgen, and the other battle- fields, to say nothing of whole ships com- panies sent to the bottom by single mines or torpedoes, may produce a movement in favor of the restoration of peace, backed by a moral momentum which not even Russian autocracy could withstand? The blood of martys is the see of the State as well as of the Church, and the victims of Mukden and the rest, will not have died wholly in vain of their blood cries out for peace with a voice that will take no denial.

div.head: Railway Travelling.—
div.p: Lately the fellaheen appear to have developed a taste lor shooting at trains, and the tiaius "de luxe" are . the favorite targets. A number of such cases have recently qccurred. On Monday the Upper Egypt express was hied at near Wasta. The , windows of a carriage were -bepken and a European traveller wounded. When a high official or a distinguished tourist has been killed by this -dangerous practice we ma> expect,that- steps( will be taken to deal with ^liese outrages.

div.head: Industrial' School for the Blind.
div.p: A bazaar was held yesterday for the benefit of the funds, of the above iustitutiou, at its new home in the ^.ttariu quarter. The day being a fine one, the stalls were arranged to the open air, in an enclosure adjoining the school, kindly lent for the purpose by Mr: G. B. Aldersou, who gavel the ground on which the Blind School has been erected. Many ladies connected with the Ministering Children's League presided, at the stalls, which were well tilled with laucy and useiul articles, many of them contributed by the children of the various^branches of the league, iu addition to the contributions lrom other sources. At 3 o'clock the bazaar was opened by Mrs. E. B. Goula, aifiTfc brisk busiueSs then commenced. The proceeuings were enlivened by a pro­gramme of music perlunneU by the baud of tbe^ud Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, which played till 4.3p, when au entertainment commenced in the' sohoolrooiu, where the children from Mrs. Anastas' school pertoihied in the 3 act play "Beauty aud the Beast." After thi'sthe 'Good Night Soug" by Mrs. Anastas was sung and this was followed by the Lucky Wedding Cake of ' Beauty and the Beast. ''Daring the afternoon many of the visitoisiiispeoied the variuus urtielesiu basket- work made by the pupils of the school aud many good, sales were effected.

div.head: Marquess of Anglesey Dead
div.p: The Marquess of Anglesey is dead. (Reuter.)

The fifth Marquess of Anglesey will be solely known to fame by thtf rapid and yrteeWul muitner in which he reduced a great estate to bankruptcy. Henry Cyril Paget succeeded hi» father, the fourth marquess, in 1898. He wus born ou June H>, 18751 aird married in.1898 the beautiful daughter of Sir George Chet- wynd and the Marchioness of Hastings, hut they didfawfc'itna-kfflg together. The Marquess succeeded _to^ 30,000 acres and two fine residences, Blit, his theatrical ventures, and reoklesp extravagance generally, led him to the Bankruptcy Court. The accounts of the sales that ensued have filled the columns of the English newspapers for months past, and will afford useful.material to the future writers oil the Social condition of England, in describing the life of the nobility. The Marquess- was of puny build, and his constitution was never very robust, but the news of his death has cuine as a surprise, as it was not known that he was seriously indisposed. He is succeeded by Charles Heurj Alexander Paget, spn of the late .Lord Alexander Victor Paget and the Hon* Hester Stapleton-Cotton, the daughter of the second Viscount Combepnore. Pie was bom iu 1885.

The other creations that go with the'title are Baron Paget (England) f552, by writ, Earl Of Uxbridge (Great Britain) 1784, autl* afn Irish baronhtcy, 1730. The Marquisate (United Kingdom) dates from 1815. The first peetin the family, Baron Paget of Beaudesert, was a Secretary of State in the reign of Henry VIII. IJe enjoyed high favor with that monarch, who made him a Knight of the Garter and' summoned him to parliament as a Baron,

div.head: Terrible Murder at Assiout
div.p: A terrible tragedy was enacted here yester­day. A certain sarraf (money-changer) visited a deutist iu order to have his set of ialse teeth repaired. He bad with him his purse contain­ing £162, which he intended to deposit in the ALjudirieh Treasury. The dentist's servant took notice, ou being given a piastre by the sarral to purchase tobacco, of the money in the purse aud he made up Ins mind to. obtain pos­session of it at any cost. Accordingly, when his master went to a pharmacy '■qear by to procure some drugs, he closed the door and strangled tbo poor sarraf to death, threw his hoffy in a well iu the house, took the' money to his mother's' house, aud returned to the clinic to resume work, as if nothing had happened.

On his return, the dentist noticed that his nervaiit was in a state of confusion, and found traces ot biooCson bis hands and clothes. Ou asking him afotuthe sarraf he could pbtain uo satisfactory aubwer? Two hours later the deutist found the sarrat's shoes on a Window­sill in the room, and this made him suspicious of foul play. The police were informed, an enquiry was set ou foot, aud traces of blood were luund leading from the room of the clinic to the well. A diver was soon brought, aud ou descending the. well he found the poor sarraf's body iu a tetrible condition. The servant was interrogated and his house sekrejb- ed. There, iu his mother's box, were found the shawl of his victim, his registers, notes, books, and set of teeth, together with a portion ot theTnouey. Tne man was arrested aud will shortly be cotnmitted for trial.

It is to" be noted that 'this is the fourth "crime" (felony) which has taken place in the town ot Assiout th.s year. > I really think that the police authorities should make a better distribution of ghaffirs and ^policemen in the streets. The crime I have related was com­mitted ,at midday, and iu a house that is situated in the main thoroughfare of tbe'town. The victim mqst have certainly cried out for help, but nptfe was forthcoming because there was no policeman there.

div.head: The Fig Tree Diseases Ravages in Ramleh
div.p: For,some time Mtt it has been noticed (hat the fig trees "at Miistdpha Pasha and on (he eatatea-near the Mahuioudieh Canal have been very 'seriously attacked by more than one disease. Mustapha Pasha is within a quarter of & mile^of the important fig groves of Sidi Gaber, and it is^be fearecT*that Unless precau­tionary measures are taken, the disease will quickly spread, and the crop at S^idi Gaber be considerably reduced iniYMue.

A well-grown tree at Mustapha, which in the old days bore, fruit to the value .of £3, now only gives a return of P.T. 20. If this can be taken as an example of what may happen at Sidi Gaber the loss will be enormous.

Specimens from the infected trees wore sent to the Khedivial Agricultural Society,.and- their entomologist, Mr. Frank C. Willoocljs, has kindly sent ' the interesting report which we publish Wow. Unfortunately the remedies which' he suggests are beyond; the intelligence $f the simple Arab -cultivator^ but it must surely, -be worth the while of every landlord to 4>ma to the aid of bis tefiant and adopt some ineatis to eradicate a disease which in the end bannut fail to reduce the value of his property.
The following is Mr. Willcocks' report :—

T^e specimens sent fer examination are very badly infested with a scale insect (a sterols- canium pustttlqns) unfortunately only too oommon in this' country. It feeds on a great variety of plants, but is especially destructive to figAnd oleander. This insect, which is of a greenish yellow colour, fringed and' sparsely covered with piiikish hairs, plunges its long, slender, .suckingmouth iuto the hark and sucks out the sap which would otherwise go to nourish the tree. At the same time it causes a small swelling or pustule to fonn on the bark with a depression in the centre in which it lies. These pustules, when presetit in num­bers,' give the twigs and small branches a very rugose and uuhe&lthy appearance. The female scale, when mature, produces a number of eggs which are protected by her1 body*. In due course these eggs give rise to young larval scale insects which make their escape from under the now dead parent scale, and after wanderiug about for a short time^finally settle down to a sedentary life of pumpingup sap and producing another brood of young 'scales. In ;this way the attack spreads to different parts of the tree until it becomes infeeted 'all over. An attacked tree is also capable Of infecting those surrounding it, the larval scales being carried from tree to tree by various natural agencies—birds, insects, etc., so that a whole

Plantation gradually becomes infested. Judging rom the number of scales on the specimens sent, the trees mast be badly attacked gad require prompt treatment I have left tbo .question of treatment to the end. The ends of several of the twigs were dead, being honey­combed with small tunnels and perforated iu places with holes no larger than a pin's head. This is ./the work of "bark boring beetles." The female beetle chooses the end of a twig or-small branch of a sickly tree, bores through i be bark, and forms a small tonnel between the inner batk.and the sap Woods. The eggs are placed along the sides of this—the "mother gallery"—and the larva: on hatching out at once commence ta firpi tunnels more or leefe at right angles to jt, feeding on the inner bark and sap woods. The white footless maggots when mature form a small chamhgr at the end of their galleries and pupole, the adults later boring uieir w£y out through the remaining thickness of bark,leaving behind them the small shut holes, to show their point of exit These little insects always prefer a tree that has been rendered unhealthy from some cause or other — in this case the attacks of astervleconium pustulans—and will spread from one tree to all the surrounding sickly ones. The signs of their attack are dead and dying twigsanosmall branches,and the presenceofthesmall shotholee. 1 have yet. to record the finding of the larva of ik boring beetle- tunneling up the centre oi one twig, but in This state it is impossible to say to what beetle it belongs. From the number of injects found, I should say that the trees are in a very bad' state, and reqnire prompt treatment to'get them into a health­ier condition. The primary etiuse is the scale inseot (asteroleeohium jntstulans), but of oourae there may be other causes at worik— bad cnltaral methods, unsuitable, soil, etc., which give the scale a greater hold, on the trees.
Treatment for a Pustulans

The trees should be sprayed or painted! with kerosene emulsion. For large trees and {Tress a nroper spraying outfit would be ne­cessary, but for small trees and plantations a knapsack spraying machine might be Sised. Similarly, painting can only be carried out on small drees and the trunks and larger branches. If, in a plantation, only a few trees are badly infested the best plan wonld to be ent them dosa^and burn them. Branches and twigs that are badly attacked should be cut out and destroyed, also dead and dying wood.

In planting young stock it is most impor­tant that it snoald be free of scale from the start, any that is infested should be remorse lessly rejected. Toe following is the formula and method of preparation for kerosene emul- sioti.
Kerosene 2 gallons.
Soft or hard soap J 1).
Boiling water 1 gallon.
Dissolve the soap in the boiling water and

whilst still boiling hot, stir in the kerosene, (reduce the fire or take vessel off when doing this), then emulsify by means of a force pump or good powerful hand syringe, until you have a creamy yellow liquid which thickens on oooling. This is the stock solution and if well made will keep for some time. When required forluse, dilute with from four to thirty times its hulk of water, according to what strength the foliage will stand, and that which is found most suitable for destroying the scale. If used as a paint dilate with four times its bulk of water.

Bark beetles.—The trees should be carefully examined for signs of these beetles,and infested twigs and branches should be cat off and destroyed. Trees that are found to be badly infested all over had best be destroyed,as thsy wre^pnly a menace to others that are in an unhealthy condition. This should be done in May, n at that time the msjority of the intents will bq iii Jaml

Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.

div.head: Football Saint Andrew's Royal Berks' Drummers
div.p: This return match was played at'Moharrei 9t". Bey on Saturday before a good tern out c ^ , spectators. The Drummers having lost tb ^ toss, Jacked off with the sun in that eyes. j little-headway was made an the left, and quit <eariy Curtis was tested, the ball, however,goin
by.' For five minutes or so both teams playe
very carefully, end little apparently was give

awAy by either, but finally the Samts show© 0 up better, not, however,managing to get throug 0 the defence. Play opened out very considerabl 0- and a lively time ensued down at the Drun in mere' end, but everything was made safe b

ily Campkin and Hammond.The visitors evidentl looked to Wallace to open the scoring,as it wa 17, seen that he was being well fed by both wingi and they were not disappoihted,for he was see iffi- to spank away through half backs, and bee in Curtis. The. Saints were quick to retaliai Sweet taking the hall well down the line an centering to Partridge, who very cleverl headed through, thus bribging the tean again levqL - Later Keill put across 1 Tulloch,, who centred in good style, Joni capping hy just touching past Clarke. If an; thing the onffits 'did more attacking.thau the ion opponents, but their shooting was very iar c ate the desirable. The Drummers could seldom gi away, and when they did get beyond the hon Of a halves Hopkins aod bis partner were alwa; ven at hand to stop their progress. Ashton (or tl the Samts was doing good work, tackling at i to feeding well. Keill got possession and ran rigl his through the defence, but his shot hit tl crossbar and rebounded, into play. Soon aft Partridge had hard lines in not sooring. Tl ; wing men of the borne team were doing exc< l lent work. Sweet in particular playing a got game, and the inside men were backing the up in nioe fashion. Half time arrived with tl ; soon Saint Andrews 2, Drummers 1.
From, the restart the Drummers went awi with a rash, and keeping the ball well under control it was worked down to Curias, but tl custodian had no difficulty in'clearing.

j was the only oocasion during this half the visitors looked dangerous, The Saidts tm g ' the game in band, and a third goal came way from Partridge, who beat Clarke fro q clds^in. A feature of the visitors' defence wi 2 the panting out of Clarke, who was keeping good goal. The home insidd men had lotsopportunities to pot through, but bad shootii ipe- lost them several -points. Keill ultimately fouithe net and thus made the soore 4 -f-1. As 6 final effort the Drummers endeavoured on 2 more to get through to Curtis. Their n I looked all right, hot

div.head: Football cont.
div.p: too much for them. The following were the teams

Saint Andrew's:- Curtis, Hopkins, A. N , Other, Williams, Ashton, MacLardy, Sweet, Keill, Partridge, Jones, and Tulloch.
It should be mentioned that the Drummer, were considerably uqder their usual strength and it was with great difficulty that thej , could get a team together to play the match

div.head: The Oldest Man in America
div.p: Tells how he escaped the terrors of many winters by using Pe-ru-na.
Born before the United States was fbrmed
Saw 22 Presidents elected.
Pe-ru-nm has protected him lrom all sudden changes.
Veteran ot mar wars.
Shod a horse when 99 years old.
Always conquered the grip with Peruna. j
Witness In a land suit at the age of 110 years.
Believes' Peruna the greatest remedy of the age for catarrhal diseases. \

ISAAC BROCK, a citizen of McLen­nan county, Texas, ham lived fpr lli years. For many years he resided at Bosque fFall, eighteen miles west ol Waco,'but now lives with his son-in-law at Valley Mills, Texas.
A short time ago, by request, Uncle Isaac came to Waco and sat for his -pic­ture, In bit band he hold a stick cut

i from the grave of General Andrew | Jackson; which has been carried by him 1 ever since. Mr. Brock is a dignified old ! gentleman, showing few signs of de-crepiuide. His family Bible is slfll pre­served, and it shows that the date of his birth was written 115 years ago. i Bnrely a few words from this remarka- 1 ble old gentleman, who has bad 115 i years of experience to draw from, would 1 be Interesting as well as profitable.
